text: [Music]
well I think I have no doubt that I got
my basic moral sort of compass from
Sunday school and my parents as it well
um and
so and I don't wanted to sort of as it
were deny or hide any of that um but
that has to do with where it comes from
and where an idea comes from doesn't
settle the question whether it's right
or not uh so some of the moral ideas
that I was raised with I think were
incorrect so the version of it I hold
isn't exactly the version I was taught
in Sunday school um I don't for example
believe in the Golden Rule I think that
the golden rule is is misf framed but
um but I do feel that that's an
important part of where I where I came
from
uh how important religion should be as a
source of ideas both about morality and
about metaphysics about what the world
is like about who made us if anybody and
and how the universe was made and so on
um of course depends on which whether
whether any religious claims are correct
uh clearly if uh if the central claims
of say Buddhist metaphysics are correct
then then the Buddhist world view is the
correct view and it's a it should be the
source of your your views if you know
that because of our rather poor
epistemological situ situation I don't
think most of us are very well placed to
decide what the correct metaphysical
view is uh which of the religious
Traditions is right about what if
anything but people have to live with
the views that they have I think they
should sustain them uh subject them to
some kind of analysis reflection uh
perhaps even criticism but still even if
you do that you're going to end up with
a with a view that uh is going to be
different from the views of lots of
other people and you're going to have to
live in a world where that's true where
lots of people have different views
about these religious questions and
you're not likely in the course of a
lifetime to be able to persuade any
single person round to the same view as
you have uh and nor are you going to be
able to come to consensus with them at
some view in between your view and
theirs and so we have to learn to live
in a world in which because we're in a
poor epistemological situation because
we're not well placed to find out the
truth we have to accept that other
people will have views that are
different from ours on some very
important questions and that there's not
much we can do uh to come to to
agreement about that though I think
there is something we can do to try and
understand uh other people's points of
view and to learn from that I think even
the most um sort of thoughtful and
convinced atheist has things to learn
from talking to people uh in religious
Traditions whether or not she recognizes
it and and vice versa people in
religious Traditions I think have things
to learn learn from each other and from
from non-religious people if they're
willing to engage in the conversation
but the conversation if the conversation
is Guided by the thought that you know 3
weeks from now we'll come to agreement
then that's that's that's that's a
mistake and you're setting yourself up
for disappointment
[Music]
